comment_text.dn34:1.1.3: This discourse is similar to DN 33; seventy items are shared between the two. Here Sāriputta teaches without prompting. The scheme is more rigorous; items listed according to a specific pattern, then the same pattern is amplified one by one. The constraints of this scheme mean that, while almost all the items listed here are found elsewhere, they are mostly not known by the name used here. This sutta seems a little later than DN 33, but such conclusions should be drawn cautiously; in at least one detail, the absence of the asura realm from the “lost opportunities”, the passage here is earlier.
comment_text.dn34:1.1.7: The use of a verse to introduce the teachings is unusual.
comment_text.dn34:1.1.10: This echoes Chāndogya Upaniṣad 7.26.2, sarvagranthīnāṁ vipramokṣaḥ.
comment_text.dn34:1.2.1: Each number from one to ten follows this same scheme.
comment_text.dn34:1.2.9: Compare SN 22.48:2.2, but this is the five aggregates rather than contact.
comment_text.dn34:1.2.21: This term is only found in the Ratanasutta (Snp 2.1:5.2). It means a kind of meditation that results in the realization of the Dhamma in this very life.
comment_text.dn34:1.3.29: The “unconditioned element” is Nibbāna, everything else is conditioned.
comment_text.dn34:1.4.3: With the addition of “rational application of mind” at AN 4.249.
comment_text.dn34:1.4.31: These three “portions” of knowledge are not found elsewhere, but compare eg. SN 12.34.
comment_text.dn34:1.6.13: A different group of five factors of immersion is at AN 5.28; the final factor is the same in both. The first four factors, however, appear only as part of this same group in later texts (Ne 21:5.1, Ps 1.1:246.2, Vb 16:342.2).
comment_text.dn34:2.1.132: At this point, DN 33:3.2.53 has an extra possibility, rebirth among the titans, making nine in all.
comment_text.dn34:2.1.145: The negative is absent from the text due to abbreviation, so it is inferred from the parallel passage at DN 33:3.2.69.
comment_text.dn34:2.2.3: Similar sequences are found throughout the suttas, but this exact sequence appears to be unique.
comment_text.dn34:2.2.7: Four are found at AN 4.194. Seven, phrased slightly differently, are found at MN 23.
comment_text.dn34:2.3.128: The sutta, and hence the Dīgha Nikāya as a whole, ends with the qualities of the arahant, the one who completes the path and practice of the Buddha.

root_text.dn34:1.7.38: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca, mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi. Na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
root_text.dn34:1.7.39: Aṭṭhānametaṁ āvuso anavakāso yaṁ mettāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya.
root_text.dn34:1.7.40: Atha ca panassa byāpādo cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.dn34:1.7.41: Nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, byāpādassa, yadidaṁ mettācetovimuttī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.43: ‘karuṇā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā.
root_text.dn34:1.7.44: Atha ca pana me vihesā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.45: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo, ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca, mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi …pe…
root_text.dn34:1.7.46: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, vihesāya, yadidaṁ karuṇācetovimuttī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.49: atha ca pana me arati cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.51: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, aratiyā, yadidaṁ muditācetovimuttī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.54: atha ca pana me rāgo cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.56: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, rāgassa yadidaṁ upekkhācetovimuttī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.59: atha ca pana me nimittānusāri viññāṇaṁ hotī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.61: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, sabbanimittānaṁ yadidaṁ animittā cetovimuttī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.63: ‘asmīti kho me vigataṁ, ayamahamasmīti na samanupassāmi,
root_text.dn34:1.7.64: atha ca pana me vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.65: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca, mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
root_text.dn34:1.7.66: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṁ asmīti vigate ayamahamasmīti asamanupassato.
root_text.dn34:1.7.67: Atha ca panassa vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.dn34:1.7.68: Nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallassa, yadidaṁ asmimānasamugghāto’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.72: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
root_text.dn34:1.7.77: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
root_text.dn34:1.7.81: dassanānuttariyaṁ, savanānuttariyaṁ, lābhānuttariyaṁ, sikkhānuttariyaṁ, pāricariyānuttariyaṁ, anussatānuttariyaṁ.
root_text.dn34:1.7.85: idhāvuso, bhikkhu anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṁ tirobhāvaṁ; tirokuṭṭaṁ tiropākāraṁ tiropabbataṁ asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ karoti seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁmahiddhike evaṁmahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vatteti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.86: Dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike ca.
root_text.dn34:1.7.87: Parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti,
root_text.dn34:1.7.88: sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ sarāgaṁ cittanti pajānāti …pe…
root_text.dn34:1.7.89: avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ avimuttaṁ cittanti pajānāti.
root_text.dn34:1.7.90: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.dn34:1.7.91: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti …pe…
root_text.dn34:1.7.92: Āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn34:1.7.94: Iti ime saṭṭhi dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.1: Satta dhammā bahukārā …pe… satta dhammā sacchikātabbā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.4: saddhādhanaṁ, sīladhanaṁ, hiridhanaṁ, ottappadhanaṁ, sutadhanaṁ, cāgadhanaṁ, paññādhanaṁ.
root_text.dn34:1.8.8: satisambojjhaṅgo, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo, vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, pītisambojjhaṅgo, passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, samādhisambojjhaṅgo, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo.
root_text.dn34:1.8.12: santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.14: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.16: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.18: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.20: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā …pe… ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.22: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.24: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.29: kāmarāgānusayo, paṭighānusayo, diṭṭhānusayo, vicikicchānusayo, mānānusayo, bhavarāgānusayo, avijjānusayo.
root_text.dn34:1.8.33: idhāvuso, bhikkhu assaddho hoti, ahiriko hoti, anottappī hoti, appassuto hoti, kusīto hoti, muṭṭhassati hoti, duppañño hoti.
root_text.dn34:1.8.37: idhāvuso, bhikkhu saddho hoti, hirimā hoti, ottappī hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, upaṭṭhitassati hoti, paññavā hoti.
root_text.dn34:1.8.41: idhāvuso, bhikkhu dhammaññū ca hoti atthaññū ca attaññū ca mattaññū ca kālaññū ca parisaññū ca puggalaññū ca.
root_text.dn34:1.8.45: aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, asubhasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.49: idhāvuso, bhikkhu sikkhāsamādāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca sikkhāsamādāne avigatapemo.
root_text.dn34:1.8.50: Dhammanisantiyā tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca dhammanisantiyā avigatapemo.
root_text.dn34:1.8.51: Icchāvinaye tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca icchāvinaye avigatapemo.
root_text.dn34:1.8.52: Paṭisallāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca paṭisallāne avigatapemo.
root_text.dn34:1.8.53: Vīriyārambhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca vīriyārambhe avigatapemo.
root_text.dn34:1.8.54: Satinepakke tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca satinepakke avigatapemo.
root_text.dn34:1.8.55: Diṭṭhipaṭivedhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca diṭṭhipaṭivedhe avigatapemo.
root_text.dn34:1.8.59: idhāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārā yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti.
root_text.dn34:1.8.60: Yaṁpāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārā yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti, idampi khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno balaṁ hoti, yaṁ balaṁ āgamma khīṇāsavo bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayaṁ paṭijānāti: ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti.
root_text.dn34:1.8.61: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aṅgārakāsūpamā kāmā yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti.
root_text.dn34:1.8.63: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno vivekaninnaṁ cittaṁ hoti vivekapoṇaṁ vivekapabbhāraṁ vivekaṭṭhaṁ nekkhammābhirataṁ byantībhūtaṁ sabbaso āsavaṭṭhāniyehi dhammehi.
root_text.dn34:1.8.65: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā honti subhāvitā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.67: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni honti subhāvitāni.
root_text.dn34:1.8.69: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā honti subhāvitā.
root_text.dn34:1.8.71: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvito hoti subhāvito.
root_text.dn34:1.8.72: Yaṁpāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvito hoti subhāvito, idampi khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno balaṁ hoti, yaṁ balaṁ āgamma khīṇāsavo bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayaṁ paṭijānāti:
root_text.dn34:1.8.75: Itime sattati dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
root_text.dn34:2.1.1: Aṭṭha dhammā bahukārā …pe… aṭṭha dhammā sacchikātabbā.
root_text.dn34:2.1.3: Aṭṭha hetū aṭṭha paccayā ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattanti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.5: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthāraṁ upanissāya viharati aññataraṁ vā garuṭṭhāniyaṁ sabrahmacāriṁ, yatthassa tibbaṁ hirottappaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti pemañca gāravo ca.
root_text.dn34:2.1.6: Ayaṁ paṭhamo hetu paṭhamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati.
root_text.dn34:2.1.7: Taṁ kho pana satthāraṁ upanissāya viharati aññataraṁ vā garuṭṭhāniyaṁ sabrahmacāriṁ, yatthassa tibbaṁ hirottappaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti pemañca gāravo ca. Te kālena kālaṁ upasaṅkamitvā paripucchati paripañhati:
root_text.dn34:2.1.10: Tassa te āyasmanto avivaṭañceva vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca uttānīkaronti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṁ paṭivinodenti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.11: Ayaṁ dutiyo hetu dutiyo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya, vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati.
root_text.dn34:2.1.12: Taṁ kho pana dhammaṁ sutvā dvayena vūpakāsena sampādeti—kāyavūpakāsena ca cittavūpakāsena ca.
root_text.dn34:2.1.13: Ayaṁ tatiyo hetu tatiyo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati.
root_text.dn34:2.1.14: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
root_text.dn34:2.1.15: Ayaṁ catuttho hetu catuttho paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati.
root_text.dn34:2.1.16: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo. Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthā sabyañjanā kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
root_text.dn34:2.1.17: Ayaṁ pañcamo hetu pañcamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati.
root_text.dn34:2.1.18: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
root_text.dn34:2.1.19: Ayaṁ chaṭṭho hetu chaṭṭho paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati.
root_text.dn34:2.1.20: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato. Cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
root_text.dn34:2.1.21: Ayaṁ sattamo hetu sattamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati.
root_text.dn34:2.1.22: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu, udayabbayānupassī viharati:
root_text.dn34:2.1.23: ‘iti rūpaṁ iti rūpassa samudayo iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
root_text.dn34:2.1.24: iti vedanā iti vedanāya samudayo iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo;
root_text.dn34:2.1.25: iti saññā iti saññāya samudayo iti saññāya atthaṅgamo;
root_text.dn34:2.1.26: iti saṅkhārā iti saṅkhārānaṁ samudayo iti saṅkhārānaṁ atthaṅgamo;
root_text.dn34:2.1.27: iti viññāṇaṁ iti viññāṇassa samudayo iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.28: Ayaṁ aṭṭhamo hetu aṭṭhamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati.
root_text.dn34:2.1.32: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
root_text.dn34:2.1.36: lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṁsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca.
root_text.dn34:2.1.40: micchādiṭṭhi, micchāsaṅkappo, micchāvācā, micchākammanto, micchāājīvo, micchāvāyāmo, micchāsati, micchāsamādhi.
root_text.dn34:2.1.46: ‘kammaṁ kho me kātabbaṁ bhavissati, kammaṁ kho pana me karontassa kāyo kilamissati, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.47: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṁ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
root_text.dn34:2.1.49: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṁ kataṁ hoti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.51: ‘ahaṁ kho kammaṁ akāsiṁ, kammaṁ kho pana me karontassa kāyo kilanto, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.54: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gantabbo hoti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.56: ‘maggo kho me gantabbo bhavissati, maggaṁ kho pana me gacchantassa kāyo kilamissati, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.59: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gato hoti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.61: ‘ahaṁ kho maggaṁ agamāsiṁ, maggaṁ kho pana me gacchantassa kāyo kilanto, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.64: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto na labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ.
root_text.dn34:2.1.66: ‘ahaṁ kho gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto nālatthaṁ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ, tassa me kāyo kilanto akammañño, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti …pe…
root_text.dn34:2.1.68: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ.
root_text.dn34:2.1.70: ‘ahaṁ kho gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto alatthaṁ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ, tassa me kāyo garuko akammañño, māsācitaṁ maññe, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.73: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno uppanno hoti appamattako ābādho, tassa evaṁ hoti:
root_text.dn34:2.1.74: ‘uppanno kho me ayaṁ appamattako ābādho atthi kappo nipajjituṁ, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.77: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gilānāvuṭṭhito hoti aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
root_text.dn34:2.1.80: Tassa me kāyo dubbalo akammañño, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.86: Idhāvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṁ kātabbaṁ hoti, tassa evaṁ hoti:
root_text.dn34:2.1.87: ‘kammaṁ kho me kātabbaṁ bhavissati, kammaṁ kho pana me karontena na sukaraṁ buddhānaṁ sāsanaṁ manasikātuṁ, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.88: So vīriyaṁ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
root_text.dn34:2.1.90: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṁ kataṁ hoti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.92: ‘ahaṁ kho kammaṁ akāsiṁ, kammaṁ kho panāhaṁ karonto nāsakkhiṁ buddhānaṁ sāsanaṁ manasikātuṁ, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
root_text.dn34:2.1.94: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gantabbo hoti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.96: ‘maggo kho me gantabbo bhavissati, maggaṁ kho pana me gacchantena na sukaraṁ buddhānaṁ sāsanaṁ manasikātuṁ, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
root_text.dn34:2.1.98: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gato hoti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.100: ‘ahaṁ kho maggaṁ agamāsiṁ, maggaṁ kho panāhaṁ gacchanto nāsakkhiṁ buddhānaṁ sāsanaṁ manasikātuṁ, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
root_text.dn34:2.1.102: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto na labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ.
root_text.dn34:2.1.104: ‘ahaṁ kho gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto nālatthaṁ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ, tassa me kāyo lahuko kammañño, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
root_text.dn34:2.1.106: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ.

root_text.dn34:2.1.115: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gilānā vuṭṭhito hoti aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
root_text.dn34:2.1.117: ‘ahaṁ kho gilānā vuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ me ābādho paccudāvatteyya, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
root_text.dn34:2.1.118: So vīriyaṁ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.

translation_text.dn34:1.7.49: Yet somehow discontent still occupies my mind.’
translation_text.dn34:1.7.50: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …
translation_text.dn34:1.7.51: For it is the heart’s release by rejoicing that is the escape from discontent.’
translation_text.dn34:1.7.53: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by equanimity. …
translation_text.dn34:1.7.54: Yet somehow desire still occupies my mind.’
translation_text.dn34:1.7.55: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …
translation_text.dn34:1.7.56: For it is the heart’s release by equanimity that is the escape from desire.’
translation_text.dn34:1.7.58: ‘I’ve developed the signless release of the heart. …
translation_text.dn34:1.7.59: Yet somehow my consciousness still follows after signs.’
translation_text.dn34:1.7.60: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …
translation_text.dn34:1.7.61: For it is the signless release of the heart that is the escape from all signs.’
translation_text.dn34:1.7.63: ‘I’m rid of the conceit “I am”. And I don’t regard anything as “I am this”.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.64: Yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupies my mind.’
translation_text.dn34:1.7.65: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.66: It’s impossible, reverend, it cannot happen that the conceit “I am” has been done away with, and nothing is regarded as “I am this”,
translation_text.dn34:1.7.67: yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupy the mind.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.68: For it is the uprooting of the conceit “I am” that is the escape from the dart of doubt and indecision.’
translation_text.dn34:1.7.72: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.73: Hearing a sound with their ears …
translation_text.dn34:1.7.74: Smelling an odor with their nose …
translation_text.dn34:1.7.75: Tasting a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.dn34:1.7.76: Feeling a touch with their body …
translation_text.dn34:1.7.77: Knowing an idea with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.79: What six things should be directly known?
translation_text.dn34:1.7.81: the unsurpassable seeing, listening, acquisition, training, service, and recollection.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.85: A mendicant wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.86: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.87: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.90: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.91: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.92: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn34:1.7.94: So these sixty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.3: Seven riches of the noble ones:
translation_text.dn34:1.8.4: the riches of faith, ethics, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.8: mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.10: What seven things should be completely understood?
translation_text.dn34:1.8.12: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.13: This is the first plane of consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.14: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in the Divinity’s host through the first absorption.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.15: This is the second plane of consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.16: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.17: This is the third plane of consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.18: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods of universal beauty.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.19: This is the fourth plane of consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.20: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.21: This is the fifth plane of consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.22: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.23: This is the sixth plane of consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.24: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.25: This is the seventh plane of consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.27: What seven things should be given up?
translation_text.dn34:1.8.29: sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.33: a mendicant is faithless, shameless, imprudent, unlearned, lazy, unmindful, and witless.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.37: a mendicant is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.39: What seven things are hard to comprehend?
translation_text.dn34:1.8.40: Seven aspects of the teachings of the true persons:
translation_text.dn34:1.8.41: a mendicant knows the teachings, knows the meaning, knows themselves, knows moderation, knows the right time, knows assemblies, and knows individuals.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.45: the perception of impermanence, the perception of not-self, the perception of ugliness, the perception of drawbacks, the perception of giving up, the perception of fading away, and the perception of cessation.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.47: What seven things should be directly known?
translation_text.dn34:1.8.49: A mendicant has a keen enthusiasm to undertake the training …
translation_text.dn34:1.8.55: to penetrate theoretically. And they don’t lose these desires in the future.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.58: Seven powers of one who has ended the defilements.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.59: Firstly, a mendicant with defilements ended has clearly seen with right wisdom all conditions as truly impermanent.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.60: This is a power that a mendicant who has ended the defilements relies on to claim: ‘My defilements have ended.’
translation_text.dn34:1.8.61: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has clearly seen with right wisdom that sensual pleasures are truly like a pit of glowing coals. …
translation_text.dn34:1.8.63: Furthermore, the mind of a mendicant with defilements ended slants, slopes, and inclines to seclusion. They’re withdrawn, loving renunciation, and have totally eliminated defiling influences. …
translation_text.dn34:1.8.65: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …
translation_text.dn34:1.8.67: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the five faculties. …
translation_text.dn34:1.8.69: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the seven awakening factors. …
translation_text.dn34:1.8.71: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the noble eightfold path. …
translation_text.dn34:1.8.72: This is a power that a mendicant who has ended the defilements relies on to claim:
translation_text.dn34:1.8.75: So these seventy things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.
translation_text.dn34:1.8.76: The first recitation section is finished.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.3: There are eight causes and reasons that lead to acquiring the wisdom fundamental to the spiritual life, and to its increase, growth, development, and fulfillment once it has been acquired.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.5: It’s when a mendicant lives relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role. And they set up a keen sense of conscience and prudence for them, with warmth and respect.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.7: When a mendicant lives relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role—with a keen sense of conscience and prudence for them, with warmth and respect—from time to time they go and ask them questions:
translation_text.dn34:2.1.10: Those venerables clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.12: After hearing that teaching they perfect withdrawal of both body and mind.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.14: Furthermore, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.16: Furthermore, a mendicant is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.18: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.20: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.22: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.23: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.24: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.25: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.26: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.27: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.31: The noble eightfold path, that is:
translation_text.dn34:2.1.32: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.34: What eight things should be completely understood?
translation_text.dn34:2.1.36: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.38: What eight things should be given up?
translation_text.dn34:2.1.40: wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.44: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.46: ‘I have some work to do. But while doing it my body will get tired. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.47: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.48: This is the first ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.49: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.51: ‘I’ve done some work. But while working my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.52: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.53: This is the second ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.54: Furthermore, a mendicant has to go on a journey.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.56: ‘I have to go on a journey. But while walking my body will get tired. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.57: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.58: This is the third ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.59: Furthermore, a mendicant has gone on a journey.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.61: ‘I’ve gone on a journey. But while walking my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.62: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.63: This is the fourth ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.64: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.66: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is tired and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.67: This is the fifth ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.68: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.70: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is heavy, unfit for work, like I’ve just eaten a load of beans. I’d better have a lie down.’…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.71: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.72: This is the sixth ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.73: Furthermore, a mendicant feels a little sick. They think:
translation_text.dn34:2.1.74: ‘I feel a little sick. Lying down would be good for me. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.75: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.76: This is the seventh ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.77: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.79: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. My body is weak and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.81: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.82: This is the eighth ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.86: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do. They think:
translation_text.dn34:2.1.87: ‘I have some work to do. While working it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.88: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.89: This is the first ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.90: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.92: ‘I’ve done some work. While I was working I wasn’t able to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.93: This is the second ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.94: Furthermore, a mendicant has to go on a journey.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.96: ‘I have to go on a journey. While walking it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.97: This is the third ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.98: Furthermore, a mendicant has gone on a journey.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.100: ‘I’ve gone on a journey. While I was walking I wasn’t able to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.101: This is the fourth ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.102: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.104: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is light and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.105: This is the fifth ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.106: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.108: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is strong and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.110: This is the sixth ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.111: Furthermore, a mendicant feels a little sick.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.113: ‘I feel a little sick. It’s possible this illness will worsen. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…
translation_text.dn34:2.1.114: This is the seventh ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.115: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.117: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. It’s possible the illness will come back. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.118: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.119: This is the eighth ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.121: What eight things are hard to comprehend?
translation_text.dn34:2.1.122: Eight lost opportunities for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.123: Firstly, a Realized One has arisen in the world. He teaches the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.124: But that individual has been reborn in hell.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.125: This is the first lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.126: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.127: But that individual has been reborn in the animal realm.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.128: This is the second lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.129: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.130: But that individual has been reborn in the ghost realm.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.131: This is the third lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.132: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.133: But that individual has been reborn in one of the long-lived orders of gods.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.134: This is the fourth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.135: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.136: But that individual has been reborn in the borderlands, among uneducated foreigners, where monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen do not go.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.137: This is the fifth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.138: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.139: And an individual is reborn in a central country. But they have wrong view and distorted perspective:
translation_text.dn34:2.1.140: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.141: This is the sixth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.142: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.143: And an individual is reborn in a central country. But they’re witless, dull, idiotic, and unable to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.144: This is the seventh lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.145: Furthermore, no Realized One has arisen in the world,
translation_text.dn34:2.1.146: so there is no teaching of the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One. But an individual is reborn in a central country. And they’re wise, bright, clever, and able to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.147: This is the eighth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.150: Eight thoughts of a great man.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.151: ‘This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.152: It’s for the contented, not those who lack contentment.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.153: It’s for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.154: It’s for the energetic, not the lazy.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.155: It’s for the mindful, not the unmindful.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.156: It’s for those with immersion, not those without immersion.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.157: It’s for the wise, not the witless.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.158: This teaching is for those who don’t enjoy proliferating, not for those who enjoy proliferating.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.159: What eight things should be directly known?
translation_text.dn34:2.1.161: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.163: This is the first dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.164: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.166: This is the second dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.167: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.169: This is the third dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.170: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.172: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.173: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.174: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color and blue appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.175: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.176: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.177: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.178: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.179: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.180: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.181: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.182: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color and red appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.183: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.184: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.185: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.186: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color and white appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.187: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn34:2.1.188: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.192: Having physical form, they see forms.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.194: Not perceiving physical form internally, someone see forms externally.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.198: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.200: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.202: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.204: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.206: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.
translation_text.dn34:2.1.209: So these eighty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.3: Nine things rooted in rational application of mind. When you apply the mind rationally, joy springs up. When you’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, you feel bliss. And when you’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed. When your mind is immersed, you truly know and see. When you truly know and see, you grow disillusioned. Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away you’re freed.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.6: Nine factors of trying to be pure.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.7: The factors of trying to be pure in ethics, mind, view, overcoming doubt, knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path, knowledge and vision of the practice, knowledge and vision, wisdom, and freedom.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.9: What nine things should be completely understood?
translation_text.dn34:2.2.11: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.12: This is the first abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.13: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in the Divinity’s host through the first absorption.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.14: This is the second abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.15: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.16: This is the third abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.17: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods of universal beauty.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.18: This is the fourth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.19: There are sentient beings that are non-percipient and do not experience anything, such as the gods who are non-percipient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.20: This is the fifth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.21: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.22: This is the sixth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.23: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.24: This is the seventh abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.25: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.26: This is the eighth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.27: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of nothingness. They have been reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.28: This is the ninth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.30: What nine things should be given up?
translation_text.dn34:2.2.32: Craving gives rise to searching. Searching gives rise to gaining material things. Gaining material things gives rise to evaluation. Evaluation gives rise to desire and lust. Desire and lust gives rise to attachment. Attachment gives rise to ownership. Ownership gives rise to stinginess. Stinginess gives rise to safeguarding. Owing to safeguarding, many bad, unskillful things come to be: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, disputes, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.36: Thinking: ‘They did wrong to me,’ you harbor resentment.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.37: Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong to me’ …
translation_text.dn34:2.2.39: ‘They did wrong by someone I love’ …
translation_text.dn34:2.2.40: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love’ …
translation_text.dn34:2.2.41: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love’ …
translation_text.dn34:2.2.44: Thinking: ‘They will help someone I dislike,’ you harbor resentment.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.47: Nine ways to get rid of resentment.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.48: Thinking: ‘They did wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?’ you get rid of resentment.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.49: Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong to me …’ …
translation_text.dn34:2.2.51: ‘They did wrong by someone I love …’ …
translation_text.dn34:2.2.52: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love …’ …
translation_text.dn34:2.2.53: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love …’ …
translation_text.dn34:2.2.56: Thinking: ‘They will help someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?’ you get rid of resentment.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.58: What nine things are hard to comprehend?
translation_text.dn34:2.2.60: Diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts. Diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings. Diversity of feelings gives rise to diversity of perceptions. Diversity of perceptions gives rise to diversity of thoughts. Diversity of thoughts gives rise to diversity of desires. Diversity of desires gives rise to diversity of passions. Diversity of passions gives rise to diversity of searches. Diversity of searches gives rise to diversity of gains.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.64: the perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness in food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, and fading away.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.66: What nine things should be directly known?
translation_text.dn34:2.2.68: A mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption …
translation_text.dn34:2.2.72: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.73: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.74: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.75: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.76: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.80: For someone who has attained the first absorption, sensual perceptions have ceased.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.81: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have ceased.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.82: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has ceased.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.83: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has ceased.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.84: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has ceased.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.85: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has ceased.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.86: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has ceased.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.87: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has ceased.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.88: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.
translation_text.dn34:2.2.90: So these ninety things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.1: Ten things are helpful, ten things should be developed, ten things should be completely understood, ten things should be given up, ten things make things worse, ten things lead to distinction, ten things are hard to comprehend, ten things should be produced, ten things should be directly known, ten things should be realized.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.3: Ten qualities that serve as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.4: First, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.6: This is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.9: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.10: Furthermore, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.12: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.13: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.15: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.16: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.18: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.19: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.21: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.22: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.24: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.27: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.28: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.30: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.31: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.33: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.37: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, undivided and limitless.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.38: They perceive the meditation on universal water …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.46: They perceive the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, undivided and limitless.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.48: What ten things should be completely understood?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.50: eye and sights, ear and sounds, nose and smells, tongue and tastes, body and touches.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.52: What ten things should be given up?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.54: wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.57: Ten ways of doing unskillful deeds:
translation_text.dn34:2.3.58: killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; covetousness, ill will, and wrong view.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.61: Ten ways of doing skillful deeds:
translation_text.dn34:2.3.62: refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; avoiding speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, good will, and right view.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.64: What ten things are hard to comprehend?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.65: Ten abodes of the noble ones.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.66: A mendicant has given up five factors, possesses six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has unsullied intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.67: And how has a mendicant given up five factors?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.68: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.69: That’s how a mendicant has given up five factors.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.70: And how does a mendicant possess six factors?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.71: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.72: Hearing a sound with their ears …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.73: Smelling an odor with their nose …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.74: Tasting a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.75: Feeling a touch with their body …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.76: Knowing an idea with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.77: That’s how a mendicant possesses six factors.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.78: And how does a mendicant have a single guard?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.79: It’s when a mendicant’s heart is guarded by mindfulness.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.80: That’s how a mendicant has a single guard.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.81: And how does a mendicant have four supports?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.82: After appraisal, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.83: That’s how a mendicant has four supports.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.84: And how has a mendicant cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.85: Different ascetics and brahmins have different idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth. A mendicant has cast out, cast aside, thrown out, discarded, let go of, given up, and relinquished all these.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.86: That’s how a mendicant has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.87: And how has a mendicant totally given up searching?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.88: It’s when they’ve given up searching for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.89: That’s how a mendicant has totally given up searching.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.90: And how does a mendicant have unsullied intentions?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.91: It’s when they’ve given up sensual, malicious, and cruel intentions.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.92: That’s how a mendicant has unsullied intentions.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.93: And how has a mendicant stilled the physical process?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.94: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.95: That’s how a mendicant has stilled the physical process.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.96: And how is a mendicant well freed in mind?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.97: It’s when a mendicant’s mind is freed from greed, hate, and delusion.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.98: That’s how a mendicant is well freed in mind.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.99: And how is a mendicant well freed by wisdom?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.100: It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘I’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’
translation_text.dn34:2.3.105: That’s how a mendicant’s mind is well freed by wisdom.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.109: the perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness in food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.111: What ten things should be directly known?
translation_text.dn34:2.3.113: For one of right view, wrong view is worn away.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.114: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong view are worn away.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.115: For one of right intention, wrong intention is worn away. …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.116: For one of right speech, wrong speech is worn away. …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.117: For one of right action, wrong action is worn away. …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.118: For one of right livelihood, wrong livelihood is worn away. …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.119: For one of right effort, wrong effort is worn away. …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.120: For one of right mindfulness, wrong mindfulness is worn away. …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.121: For one of right immersion, wrong immersion is worn away. …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.122: For one of right knowledge, wrong knowledge is worn away. …
translation_text.dn34:2.3.123: For one of right freedom, wrong freedom is worn away.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.124: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong freedom are worn away.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.128: an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.130: So these hundred things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.”
translation_text.dn34:2.3.131: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.
translation_text.dn34:2.3.132: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what Sāriputta said.
